channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Barbra Streisand on Her Early Recordings: ‘That Girl Can Sing’
item.description: “Live at the Bon Soir,” a restored set of songs from November 1962, allows listeners today — and Streisand, herself — to rediscover the sounds of a star being born.
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris

item.title: ‘The Crown’ Has a New Diana and Charles to Tear Apart
item.description: Season 5 tracks the collapse of the royals’ marriage. In a joint interview, Elizabeth Debicki and Dominic West discuss the challenge of taking on these roles and the scrutiny the show has received since Queen Elizabeth’s death.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: For ‘Fleishman Is in Trouble,’ Claire Danes and Jesse Eisenberg Say I Do
item.description: The actors share a doomed union in this new FX series. In a joint interview, they discuss their own marriages and how it felt to depict such a contentious one.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times
item.media:description: In “Fleishman Is in Trouble,” Claire Danes and Jesse Eisenberg play two halves of a splintered couple.

item.title: For ‘KPOP,’ a Broadway Transfer Is More Like a Reinvention
item.description: The show’s creative team talks about revamping the immersive Off Broadway hit so that it moves “around the audience” at Circle in the Square Theater.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

item.title: Louis Armstrong’s Last Laugh
item.description: Private recordings, heard in the new documentary “Louis Armstrong’s Black & Blues,” add a further dimension to the artist.
item.dc:creator: Alan Scherstuhl

item.title: Where the Sky Meets the Sea: Jennifer Guidi Leans Into Beauty
item.description: The artist’s new show at David Kordansky Gallery reveals her spiritual sensibility and inspires the pleasures of looking.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Curators have increasingly come to recognize the depth and complexity of Jennifer Guidi’s art. “It’s more than it initially appears,” said one museum director.

item.title: ‘Mood’ Is a Genre-Bending Show About Social Media and Sex Work
item.description: “Mood,” a BBC America series created by Nicôle Lecky, blends music, comedy and gritty realism to explore the opportunities and risks for young women online.
item.dc:creator: Desiree Ibekwe
item.media:credit: Ellie Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: In her show “Mood,” Nicôle Lecky explores the gray area between empowerment and exploitation.

item.title: Britain’s Major Opera Companies Suffer in Arts Spending Shake-Up
item.description: English National Opera lost its government subsidy, and the Royal Opera House received a 10-percent cut, with funding diverted to organizations outside London.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Chris Jackson/Chris Jackson Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The auditorium of the Coliseum theater, home to English National Opera.

item.title: Selena Gomez’s Boldly Revealing Ballad, and 9 More New Songs
item.description: Hear tracks by Yves Tumor, Yo La Tengo, Sipho and others.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include films about fighting for survival, the thrill of revenge and brazen hackers.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.media:description: Marwan Abdulla Saleh in “The Ambush.”

item.title: How Daniel Radcliffe Gets ‘Weird’ in ‘The Al Yankovic Story’
item.description: The director Eric Appel narrates a scene from the film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: How Female Playwrights Are Adapting, and Revamping, ‘Macbeth’
item.description: With “Macbeth” adaptations like “Peerless,” the inner lives of young women come into focus.
item.dc:creator: Diep Tran

item.title: Review: Davóne Tines Hones the Recital Form to a Fine Point
item.description: This bass-baritone made his Carnegie Hall debut with his carefully curated, personal “Recital No. 1: MASS.”
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr

item.title: Freddy Rodríguez, 76, Artist Who Explored His Dominican Roots, Dies
item.description: His main medium was paint, but his most viewed work may have been the outdoor memorial in Queens to Flight 587.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Out Loud, Pumped Up and Bossed Around by the French
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Claire Keegan Harnesses the Power in Brevity
item.description: Keegan doesn’t write much, or publish often. But when she does, critics, readers and booksellers take notice.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter

item.title: Dancing at Paul Taylor, a New Generation Finds Its Footing
item.description: For its Lincoln Center season, the Paul Taylor Dance Company presents premieres by Lauren Lovette and Amy Hall Garner, along with the classics.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:description: John Harnage in the premiere of “Solitaire” by the company’s resident choreographer, Lauren Lovette. A new era of dancers at Paul Taylor moves with the same gusto and grit as those who came before.

item.title: Review: A Parade of People, Pulled by Many Forces
item.description: The Brazilian troupe Lia Rodrigues Companhia de Danças makes its New York-area debut with “Fúria” as part of Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.category: Lia Rodrigues Companhia de Dancas (Dance Group)

item.title: Douglas McGrath, Playwright, Filmmaker and Actor, Is Dead at 64
item.description: His one-man Off Broadway show, “Everything’s Fine,” directed by John Lithgow, had opened just weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Douglas McGrath in 2012. He had a wide-ranging if under-the-radar career in television, film and theater.

item.title: Katherine Duncan-Jones, Who Cast Shakespeare as a Boor, Dies at 81
item.description: A fearless scholar of English literature, she argued in books and interviews that the revered playwright was a narcissist, misogynist and social climber.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: How an LAPD Officer Helped Les Moonves Fight an Assault Complaint
item.description: A captain in the department, who had moonlighted as a security guard for CBS, disclosed to the network information about a confidential complaint made in 2017 against the C.E.O.
item.dc:creator: James B. Stewart and Rachel Abrams
item.media:description: The Los Angeles Police Department has opened an investigation into the conduct of Cory Palka, who is now retired.

item.title: Review: In ‘Where the Mountain Meets the Sea,’ Missed Connections
item.description: A father and a son recall parallel journeys that reflect shared experiences of otherness in Jeff Augustin’s play, performed with music by the Bengsons.
item.dc:creator: Naveen Kumar
item.category: Where the Mountain Meets the Sea (Play)
item.media:description: From left: Chris Myers, Abigail Bengson, Shaun Bengson and Billy Eugene Jones in “Where the Mountain Meets the Sea” at New York City Center.

item.title: ‘Weird: The Al Yankovic Story’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director and co-writer Eric Appel narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Daniel Radcliffe as Weird Al Yankovic.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: What to Know About the Danny Masterson Rape Trial
item.description: The “That ’70s Show” actor has been charged with raping three women in the early 2000s. Two of the women have said the Church of Scientology discouraged them from reporting the assaults to the police.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Masterson in 2017.

item.title: Rebecca Godfrey, 54, Dies; Author Found Humanity in Teenage Violence
item.description: She drew praise for the precision and compassion of “Under the Bridge,” her account of the beating and murder of a 14-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: Under the Bridge: The True Story of the Murder of Reena Virk (Book)

item.title: Steps in the Left Direction
item.description: Playbooks for political change from Robert Kuttner and Eric Holder, and a historian’s warning about the heart of the resistance.
item.dc:creator: James Goodman
item.category: Going Big: FDR's Legacy, Biden's New Deal, and the Struggle to Save Democracy (Book)
Why White Liberals Fail: Race and Southern Politics from FDR to Trump (Book)
Our Unfinished March: The Violent Past and Imperiled Future of the Vote -- A History, A Crisis, A Plan (Book)

item.title: Review: The Met Brings Back a Shorter, Weaker ‘Don Carlo’
item.description: David McVicar’s staging from last season has returned, but in a four-act, Italian-language form. In this case, less is less.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls

item.title: Meet the Woman Planning an Underwater Highline
item.description: Part public housing for fish, part carbon-capture project, part art installation, Ximena Caminos’s project for Miami Beach, known as the ReefLine, aims to call attention to the challenges facing the city’s marine life.
item.dc:creator: Nora Walsh
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ximena Caminos, who is developing the ReefLine In Miami Beach, is an art curator, cultural placemaker and founder of the ocean-centric nonprofit BlueLab Preservation Society.

item.title: Ukrainians Turn to Diaries for Solace, and to Share Life in Wartime
item.description: Writers have long used diaries to make sense of life. Now, diaries can be shared in real time, helping shape public perception of events as they unfold — including war.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: A portrait of a volunteer of Kyiv’s Zoo Patrol, by Mila Teshaieva. Teshaieva went from Berlin to Kyiv, her hometown, when the war started, and recorded her impressions in diary entries and photos.

item.title: Between Kanye and the Midterms, the Unsettling Stream of Antisemitism
item.description: For American Jews, this fall has become increasingly worrisome. On Thursday alone, the F.B.I. warned of threats to New Jersey synagogues and the Nets suspended Kyrie Irving.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson and Ruth Graham
item.media:description: Police stand outside Temple Beth-El synagogue in Jersey City, N.J., on Thursday. The FBI said it had received credible information about a “broad” threat to synagogues in the state.

item.title: Late Night Takes Up Herschel Walker’s Résumé Challenge
item.description: The football star and Senate candidate said he’d put his accomplishments up against Barack Obama’s any time. “Bold!” said Stephen Colbert.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Estate’ Review: No Good Will
item.description: Toni Collette and Anna Faris play sisters trying to weasel their way into their wealthy aunt’s will in this black comedy.
item.dc:creator: Teo Bugbee

item.title: Review: In ‘Almost Famous,’ the Heart of Rock ’n’ Roll Flatlines
item.description: Cameron Crowe’s 2000 film, set in the world of bands and groupies, does not survive its Broadway musical transplant.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: Casey Likes, center aloft, as William Miller in the musical “Almost Famous” at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Paul Taylor Dance Company Is Accused of Gender Discrimination
item.description: A costume designer filed a lawsuit saying the company discriminated against her because she is a mother.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Barbara Delo, a costume designer who said she was fired from the Paul Taylor Dance Company after less than a year.

item.title: India Convicts Antiquities Dealer Also Facing Charges in New York
item.description: The dealer, Subhash Kapoor, has been accused by U.S. authorities of being a major trafficker who sold stolen artifacts valued at more than $100 million.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan and Tom Mashberg
item.media:credit: Amirtharaj Stephen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Subhash Kapoor being escorted to court by police officers in India in 2015. The former art dealer has been convicted on antiquities trafficking charges there after a lengthy legal process.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends checking out an enchanting cartoon, a new British musical drama and a well-done crime documentary.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.category: Wolfboy and the Everything Factory (TV Program)
item.media:description: A scene from “Wolfboy and the Everything Factory.”

item.title: A Fair Where the Art Shines (Grandstanding Not Required)
item.description: This year’s Art Show at the Park Avenue Armory cuts through the noise of politics. Painting reigns supreme, but the standouts include ceramics and works on paper.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: Artists Revisit Their Bronx Walls of Fame
item.description: John Ahearn and Rigoberto Torres spent decades capturing the verve of the borough’s residents in plaster and paint. A survey at the Bronx Museum brings their vision home.
item.dc:creator: Travis Diehl
item.media:credit: Clark Hodgin for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, visitors with “Fortune Teller," from 1995, by Rigoberto Torres, and “Margaret and Edwin,” 1992/98, by the artist, from “Swagger and Tenderness,” live-cast sculptural portraits at the Bronx Museum of the Arts by Torres and the artist John Ahearn.

item.title: Rodney Graham, Conceptual Artist Who Starred in His Work, Dies at 73
item.description: As both an artist and a model, he created alternative worlds where ordinary characters seemed extraordinary.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: The Philharmonic Tests Its New Home With the Classics
item.description: David Geffen Hall reopened with a month of concerts that sketched a possible future for the New York Philharmonic. Now it’s back to business.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

item.title: ‘Weird: The Al Yankovic Story’ Review: Any Odd? He Beat It.
item.description: The parody musician makes a joke of his own life, with the help of Daniel Radcliffe, in this uproarious sham biopic.
item.dc:creator: Amy Nicholson

item.title: Review: Ayodele Casel Returns to the Joyce With ‘Chasing Magic’
item.description: Originally a virtual production earlier in the pandemic, this live version features an improvised duet between Casel and the pianist Arturo O’Farrill.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:description: Ayodele Casel, center, and fellow dancers performing in “Chasing Magic” at the Joyce Theater.

item.title: ‘Utama’ Review: This Bitter Earth
item.description: In Bolivia’s official submission to the next Oscars, an old Quechua couple struggle to find water to sustain them, their crops and llamas.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Croatia Takes a Step Toward Returning Art Looted During the Holocaust
item.description: A study released jointly by the government and the World Jewish Restitution Organization details the plunder from Jewish estates and lists some of the works still held in Croatian museums.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hickley
item.category: Commission for the Preservation of Cultural Monuments (KOMZA)
item.media:description: A report on the art taken from Jews in what is now Croatia during the Holocaust is viewed as a step toward the return of some works to heirs. Some art went to the Strossmayer Gallery of Old Masters in Zagreb.

item.title: When Technology Makes Music More Accessible
item.description: In Britain and Ireland, a series of recent projects show the rich possibilities when disability and neurodiversity are considered in the creative process.
item.dc:creator: Hugh Morris

item.title: ‘Causeway’ Review: Companions on a Hard Road to Recovery
item.description: Superb acting from Jennifer Lawrence and Brian Tyree Henry brings credibility to an underdeveloped story of trauma and friendship.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott

item.title: A Deluge of Art at the Carnegie International
item.description: A hugely ambitious show, the 58th Carnegie International in Pittsburgh, leaves our critic wondering just who, or what, art exhibitions like this are for.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.category: Is It Morning for You Yet? (Exhibit)

item.title: ‘Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths’ Review: It’s a Stressful Afterlife
item.description: In Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s sprawling, intensely personal new film, a prominent journalist grapples with work, family, metaphysics and the paradoxes of Mexican history.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott
item.category: Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths (Movie)
item.media:description: Daniel Giménez Cacho in “Bardo.” He plays Silverio, a character who bears a resemblance to the film’s director, Alejandro G. Iñárritu.

item.title: ‘Salvatore: Shoemaker of Dreams’ Review: For the Heel of It
item.description: Luca Guadagnino’s documentary about the celebrated Italian shoe designer Salvatore Ferragamo reaches for romance and glamour, but falters during transitions.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: John David Washington Gets an Education in ‘The Piano Lesson’
item.description: The actor adds to his body of knowledge with a starry production of the August Wilson play and a once-in-a-lifetime moment with Robert De Niro on “Amsterdam.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Tess Ayano for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I want to learn. I want to get beat up,” John David Washington said, explaining why he wanted to perform in “The Piano Lesson.”

item.title: Against the Grain: Rebecca Morris and Peter Bradley’s Art ‘About Nothing’
item.description: Created half a century apart, two exhibitions in Los Angeles by two painters make ardent cases for abstraction.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Griffin

item.title: ‘Soft & Quiet’ Review: Far-Right Ladies Night
item.description: This distressingly immersive horror film by Beth de Araújo traces a group of white supremacist women in real time.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: In ‘Dangerous Liaisons,’ Alice Englert and Nicholas Denton Play the Game
item.description: In a decadent new Starz drama, the two actors play young versions of literature’s most poisoned and poisonous power couple.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Sabrina Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Denton and Alice Englert play Pascal, a young mapmaker, and Camille, a sex worker, before they become the Vicomte de Valmont and Marquise de Merteuil.

item.title: Brigitte Giraud Wins Goncourt Prize With Tragic Novel of Loss
item.description: The prestigious French literary award went to “Living Fast,” or “Vivre Vite,” which explores the causes of an accident that killed the author’s partner.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brigitte Giraud in Paris in October. Previous Goncourt winners include Marcel Proust, Simone de Beauvoir and Marguerite Duras.

item.title: Winter Movies 2022: Here’s What’s Coming Soon to Streaming and Theaters
item.description: The season’s gifts include long-awaited sequels to “Black Panther” and “Knives Out” and intriguing originals like “Women Talking” and “The Fabelmans.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Don Cheadle, Lindsay Lohan and Other Stars Share Their Favorite Holiday Movies
item.description: Don Cheadle, Hong Chau, Leslie Odom Jr., Zoey Deutch and Lindsay Lohan explain what films they turn to at this time of year.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: Review: In ‘You Resemble Me,’ a Maladjusted Girl Is Interrupted
item.description: Dina Amer’s film uses empathetic, if simplistic, fictions to try to make sense of the complicated real life of a young Moroccan-French woman drawn to ISIS.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: ‘Next Exit’ Review: End of the Road
item.description: Two strangers reflect on their lives as they embark on a cross-country drive to join a study involving life after death.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold

item.title: ‘Something in the Dirt’ Review: The Truth Is Over There, by the Sofa
item.description: Two likable losers fall into conspiratorial rabbit holes while filming the strange goings-on in their apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Nocebo’ Review: A Troubled Home and a Sick Mother
item.description: A new horror starring Eva Green has a point to make about economic exploitation but lacks a sense of surprise.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: ‘Meet Me in the Bathroom’ Review: New York’s Last Rock Renaissance
item.description: The post-post punk New York rock scene gets an archival retrospective in this documentary.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Good Night Oppy’ Review: Life (Kind of) on Mars
item.description: NASA’s Opportunity and Spirit rovers didn’t shoot cinematic-quality footage of Mars, but this documentary offers the next-best thing.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
